saves.lead_paragraph: Having invited Senator LA FOLLETTE to make a statement of his cause and case in today's TIMES, we would refer to it only with becoming courtesy. Its great lack must be obvious to every reader. This is its extreme indefiniteness. The Senator uses with vehemence a great many terms without defining one of them.

saves.abstract: Crimea remains in darkness as Tatar activists and Ukrainian nationalists block repair of power lines downed by saboteurs; Ukrainian president tacitly endorses action, aimed at forcing Russia to release political prisoners, while Russian reaction is mix of indifference and annoyance.

headline.main: As Sabotage Blacks Out Crimea, Tatars Prevent Repairs

saves.snippet: One year after they surrendered last December, life has improved for two top leaders of the brutal Khmer Rouge. No longer on the run, they live openly among their old comrades in a remote border town, free of the threat of government attack.    But...
saves.lead_paragraph: One year after they surrendered last December, life has improved for two top leaders of the brutal Khmer Rouge. No longer on the run, they live openly among their old comrades in a remote border town, free of the threat of government attack. But if they believed, as they said they hoped then, that the world would ''let bygones be bygones,'' they were wrong. And their captor, Prime Minister Hun Sen, has been forced to back away from his proposal to ''dig a hole and bury the past.''
saves.abstract: Cambodia is moving toward some sort of trials for some of former Khmer Rouge even though Prime Min Hun Sen had hoped to 'dig a hole and bury the past'; contentious questions still remain over whether any such trials will meet international standards of fairness and legal rigor; critics fear outcomes will be crafted to suit Hun Sen's political needs rather than to examine the deaths of more than a million people by Khmer Rouge (M)

headline.main: The Shape Of Justice Is Undefined In Cambodia
